8:14 Can we use entanglement to communicate faster than light?
Yes we can.
Digital information is processed and transferred in streams of bits, 1 and 0.
The sender uses the angle of the measurement to "transfer" the information. If it is a 1 that has to be transmitted, the spin will be measured horizontal. For a zero (0), the spin of the photon will be measured vertically.
For each bit the receiver will measure each photon 10 times in a row, the first 5 horizontal, the last 5 in vertical position.
For a 1, the receiver will measure the same spin direction for the first 5 measurements, and mixed direction for the other 5. (e.g. up,up,up,up,up,up,down,down,up,up)
For a 0, the receiver will measure mixed spin directions for the first 5 measurements, and the same direction for the other 5. (e.g. up,up,up,up,down,up,up,up,up,up)
So the block of 5 (first or last one) that has all same spin directions corresponds with the value of the bit.
The beauty of this solution is that the information to be transferred is not based on the spin direction itself, because that is fully random, but on the measurement angle (horizontal or vertical). If the measurement angle is the same on both sides, the spin is 100% the same, if the angles differ 90 degrees, the change is 50%.
OK, there is a change that spin directions of the "wrong angle" are all the same. The change is ½^4 = 6,25% based on 10 measurements. So it is important to adjust the number of measurements to the importance and accuracy of the information to be transferred.

There is a problem with this experiment/example. The odds of selecting the lone up/down spin are the same as the odds of getting either of the paired ones. So the use of a 2/3 and 1/3 ratio for the probabilities is wrong.

The probability of a spin at an angle is f(θ)=cos^2(θ/2). So if the detector you read returns UP then the other two detectors are likely at a more extreme angle and are more likely to return DOWN. So if you have the following sets (U,D,D),(D,U,U) in any order then you are actually more likely to have chosen the U over the two Ds or the D over the two Us. The probabilities of these are being misrepresented in the experiment.

To understand superpositions and entanglement, first you have to let go of linear time. If you imagine one moment follows the next, then quantum physics will never make sense. Feynman was half right. If you think you understand quantum physics and you think time is linear then congratulations, you don't understand quantum physics.

To make a poor analogy, it is more like how lightning happens, except the cloud is the moment entanglement happens, and the ground is when the particle is observed.

With lightning, the actual bolt is not the first thing that happens, first something that could be thought of as a probability wave (electrical potential) increases between the cloud and the ground, and tendrils of charge build up until it shorts out through the most conductive path and you get a bolt of lightning.

With light, entanglement, and some other quantum phenomena like superpositions, the particle literally bounces forwards and backwards through time, simulating a probability wave with a single particle, until the moment it is observed, at which point the last path it took is the only path it took and it is the path it always took . This is why a single particle can interact with itself in the double slit experiment, unless it is observed first. Before it is observed, it has an infinite number of paths through both slits, interacting with itself back and forth through time like a wave. But if it is observed, from that point onwards it only has one path linearly through time moving forward.

For an entangled pair, observing one fixes the other in the past, so it is and always was , the reciprocal of the first. For the example in the video, measuring the spin of one particle makes it so that the spin of the other particle always was the opposite from the moment they were entangled. It fixes, or sets, the past which up until that point was in flux.

It's not spooky action at a distance, it's spooky action through time. Viewed this way, many quantum effects which are counter-intuitive and confusing become plain and obvious.

I have a lot of objections to quantum entanglement. One objection is the testing of entangled particles. At minute 4:31 of this video, you mention that "pairs of entangled particles will be sent to the two detectors" for testing. My question is: How do you know the two particles you are sending to the detectors are entangled? Not all particles are entangled. If two entangled particles have been located for the purpose of such a test, how were they found? And how do you know these two particles are actually entangled? (Or did such testing never even take place with actual entangled particles, but the testing is nothing more than a mathematical calculation based on what one believes they might find?)

Another objection I have is that quantum entanglement implies that exerting force on one entangled particle would move both entangled particles by the same amount, even though only one of the particles was acted upon by the force. This violates a fundamental law of physics that the amount of work obtained is always equal to the amount of force applied. You cannot apply a force of "A" on an object and get the work equivalent of "2A" of force. (What I mean is: Your hardest push on a sofa moves it 1 meter forward. You tie 2 sofas together. Your hardest push will not move both sofas 1 meter forward, but only 0.5 meter, since the force of your push would be divided in half by each sofa.) Quantum entanglement implies getting double the work output for your input, giving you one workload output for free, which violates the laws of physics. If you exert enough force on particle 1 to move it 1 meter, then 2 particles that are entangled could move only 0.5 meter each; they cannot both move 1 meter each, for you cannot get work for free.

The simplest explanation for why we can't use the "spooky-action-at-a-distance" or FTL communication between entangled particles is that it doesn't exist. Two particles interact, move away from each other to distant detectors, and the results are correlated in a way that conforms to conservation law. This seems very much like what happens with, say, colliding billiard balls. Except that, prior to detection, what we're calling particles might be waves, i.e., disturbances in media of unknown substance and structure. So, let's suppose that.

Let's further suppose that these waves are continually changing in form, and therefore really don't have any particular "spin" value while they're heading for the detectors. Nevertheless, they will still be related by conservation law. In experiments designed to produce opposite values for timestamp-correlated detections, isn't referring to a relationship due to mutual interaction and application of conservation law enough to obviate the need for them to be communicating in some FTL or spooky way? Relationships of this sort don't care about distance.

The basic tests of quantum entanglement convincingly demonstrated to modern physics, with no real doubt now, that Local-Realistic theories cannot be correct. The key is what happens when you measure a spin of a particle in a direction which is not the same as the direction as when it was generated. The video says there is a 50% chance it could become up or down if the measuring was done at a 90 degree angle. Now this alone tells you that the 'spin' of the object is NOT encoded in the particle itself. An up particle can obviously be converted into a down particle and vice versa. So, yes this experiment shows that the spin is NOT permanently encoded in the particle to serve as the "hidden variable".  But what we are doing by measuring the spin at different angles, is to completely change the spin, so we get the 50% chance that is observed due to the resetting of the state, thus removing the "hidden variable" in this experiment. So the result can be explained as an 'artifact" of the experimental setup, not because we tell if there is a hidden variable or not. There is a hidden variable, but that can only be properly recovered if the detector is always in the same orientation as when it was created. In that case, we always trivially recover a 100% matching rate. If quantum entanglement were true, then there would be instances where if we observe an up spin, there is a probability that the other particle will also be up spin, because the state was indeterminate. We don't see that, therefore the concept of entanglement must be wrong and Einstein's concept of a hidden variable must be correct.

Einstein did not accept the Copenhagen interpretation, so that a particle can be +1 and -1 at the same time till the moment it is measured and that the act of measuring it collapses it to +1 (or -1) so immediately influencing the entangled one with a spooky action at a distance. 2) Therefore, it is more correct to say that we do not know in advance if a particle is +1 or -1 till the moment we measure it and that there will be a certain distribution, say 50/50. While your explanation of Bell's theorem is a good one and graphically very clear, I question the assumptions and predictions of Bell's theorem itself. I would question one thing you said, that is, that measuring a particle can change its orientation. Some physicists say that if you force the particle to change its state, you created decoherence and destroy the entanglement. Also, in the Copenhagen interpretation, the particle does not have a definite angle of spin until measured. One of your illustrations indicated that it did have a pre-existing angle of spin. Here's my critique.

Bell’s (or Bell’s interpreter’s) assumptions in his theorem are supposed to be EPR assumptions which can be reduced to absurdity, but they are not EPR assumptions. They are quantum and random assumptions.

1>EPR assumptions/predictions: When particles are created or entangled, they immediately have opposite spin 100% of the time which is necessary to preserve angular momentum. The angle of spin (somewhere between 0 and 360) is set at the time of entanglement and embedded in the twin particles, so that even if they are separated, this information remains in the particles. If one particle is spin up, the other will be spin down in the same line such as 0/180 – not in any combination of lines. There is no half-down, ¾ down correlation - there is only fully down (180-degrees apart) correlation. The whole point is to conserve angular momentum, and you can’t conserve momentum half-way or ¾ of the way. Given this interpretation, all particle pairs will have opposite and equal spin, that is, they will always be measured to have different states (A up/B down or A down/B up) and will never show the same states (A up/B up, or A down/B down). If particles show the same states, then they were not entangled to begin with.
2>Quantum (Copenhagen) assumptions/predictions: When particles are entangled, they acquire some basic information, that is, to always have opposite spin when measured, but the direction or angle of spin is undetermined until measured. The superposition interpretation is that the particles have all possible angles of spin until measured – the other interpretation is that they have no definite direction of spin before measured. So, in Q-M, half the information (particles will have opposite spin) is embedded locally, but the other half (angle of spin) is not. Since the constraint to be measured with opposite spin, even in the quantum interpretation, is built into the entanglement process to conserve angular momentum, then the prediction should be the same as EPR’s prediction – that 100% of the time the entangled particles will show opposite spin to conserve angular momentum when measured. If the pair shows the same angle of spin, then they were not entangled. However, the interpreters of Bell tell us that the odds are 50% for same spin and 50% for opposite spin. Of course, entanglement means particles will have opposite spin or different spin when measured at a distance. Is there any other meaning to the word “entanglement?” If spin is not entangled, then what is? Entanglement means that particles have mirror-correlated DNA.
3>Random pairing of particles without entanglement: The real assumption of the interpreters of Bell are that the particles are independent of each other so that sometimes particle A can be spin up and particle B can be spin up also and vice versa. If this same behavior occurs, then there is no entanglement and the odds would be 50/50 of getting a same response or getting a different response. After all, the experiment boils down to the fact that either the pair is opposite in spin or the same in spin. There are two ways of getting same spin (particle A up and particle B up or, vice versa, particle A is down and particle B is down). And, there are two ways of getting a different measurement (particle A up, particle B down or particle A down, particle B up). So, regardless of the number of detectors, it boils down to a 50/50 chance of getting the same or different response. As can be seen, the Random pairing of particles gives the same prediction as the quantum (Copenhagen) prediction – 50/50 either way. Since the quantum interpretation does not differentiate itself from the random interpretation, it is not a scientific theory because one could attribute a 50/50 result to either interpretation. There is an equality here - not an inequality. The inequality exists between the EPR interpretation and the random/quantum interpretations.

The fact that EPR, even in the flawed experiment, gives a 55+% result in particle-pairs showing opposite spin says that EPR is in the direction of its 100% prediction. At least it beats the odds. The fact that quantum theory does not beat the chance expectation of 50/50 shows that it does not really predict anything that a flip of a coin would predict. Most theories predict that the results will be a deviation from chance. To sum it up, this experiment does not differentiate between EPR and quantum interpretations.

The thing is... they DON'T have undefined spins. Many of the more bizarre assumptions of quantum theory are based on what the math "suggested"... and a few early physicists (Bohr, Heisenberg, and a few others) took those mathematical "suggestions" and assumed VERY bizarre things... things that violated literally everything that we know about the universe... extremely non-parsimonious things. Things that Occam's razor SHOULD have sliced off immediately. And those early physicists influenced more and more grad students, and now we have a whole field of professional physicists who buy into the Copenhagen interpretation instead of the almost blindingly obvious Bohmian interpretation. Luckily, there are more and more professors accepting the Bohmian interpretation, and I've been lucky enough to be a student at a university with two influential professors sympathetic to it. Spin and some other aspects are actually defined by the wave function... but that aside, any of the other aspects of entangled particles are defined at the moment of entanglement, and that state is maintained, and doesn't change.
The idea that observation/measurement somehow causes a particle or quantum system to snap into a definite state (the "collapse of the wave function") is one of those fictions "suggested" by the math, but without any actual evidence, and totally contrary to everything we know about everything else in the universe. And yes, I'm aware that "the quantum world is very non-intuitive", as so many people are so keen on saying... but this is simply an attempt to handwave away all of the non-parsimonious insanity of the Copenhagen interpretation. In 40 years, when the Bohmian interpretation is filled out and has become the obvious orthodoxy, students will literally laugh heartily when thinking back to a time when some of the supposedly most intelligent people on the planet believed in literally supernatural nonsense.

You talked about having only two "base" states that matter (uuu or uud in which u=up and d=down) due to the fact that all other states were "mathematically equivalent", which of course is true. However, the number of equivalent states for each base state are not! Hence the misunderstanding of my simulation results on my part. The full set of 3-bit states is the following:
1 - uuu (base state 1)
2 - ddd (equivalent to base state 1)
3 - uud (base state 2)
4 - udu (equivalent to base state 2)
5 - udd (equivalent to base state 2)
6 - duu (equivalent to base state 2)
7 - dud (equivalent to base state 2)
8 - ddu (equivalent to base state 2)

This means base state 1 (the all aligned state) has a probability of occuring 2/8 times, while the base state 2 states with one misaligned spin occur 6/8 of the time. This leads to a probability of detecting opposites spin of:

(2/8 x 1) + (6/8 x 5/9) = 48/72 =2/3 thus approximately 66.7%

After bashing my head over the wall for some years now, I think that I (and many others I suppose) have alas! came up with an elegant solution to 2 of the most weird concepts of Quantum Mechanics. Entangled 'particles'' and 'superposition'.
(This text is by no means to be taken more seriously than you should, but it still an idea worth thinking...)

So! How do we start?
We start with a point!
(lol no! Sorry that's from somewhere else).

~ ~ We start by imagining a 2 dimensional world called Flatland ~ ~
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Now let's imagine that me and you and everyone lives inside this Flatland world and everything lacks height! Actually there is no height at all. Not even a tiny bit of it. Nothing, zero, nil, nada. No height allowed. That means that if I fold that 2d world, one could say that the one side is going to be 'touching' the other that is folded but that's actually very wrong! (btw let's just think this flatland as a piece of paper)

Even if we fold the paper in two and press it with our hands (even if we cannot do that with a 2d paper but let's move on...) the people living on the one side and the people living at the other, won't touch - see - hear or feel in any way the other people from the other side!!!! Of Course to us that can see the 'whole picture' it will look like they do, but remember! We have 3 dimensions. They have only 2! That means that they are unaware that their world had just been folded together in a higher dimension than theirs.

But where does all a that helps?

Now imagine that we have 2 particles. Particle number A and particle number B. Let's say that these particles spin and they are entangled (when one is observed the other also reacts like it has been observed as well). And let's say that we place the 1st particle at the one side of the paper and the other at the same side but far away from the particle A. Then we fold the paper so that particle A and particle B actually "touch" each other! (they land on-top of each other).

From our perspective that's what they do! They 'touch' each other, or in other words, it seems as there is hardly and space between them. But from the flatlanders perspective, these 2 particles are very, very, very far away from each other and by no means connected. Now we run the experiment, we observe the particle A, it snaps in UP spin and then we observe the particle B that has already snapped in DOWN spin. From our 3 dimensional perspective that's not weird at all! These 2 particles they don't seem to be far apart not even the slightest, actually they appear so close as if they are actually connected with each other. No wonder that when you measure the 1st the second is also going to be observed... Something that ofcourse the Flatlanders have no way to ever know or feel or observe in any possible way. They are completely trapped within their 2 dimensions, unable to even imagine the world as it really is. Imperfect as they are, they keep seeing a world that is flat and more importantly, they keep seeing 2 particles, behaving in a 'spooky' way while being far apart from each other.

So now, we can do the same to our world and our perspective about it. We only have 3 dimensions, but, be ready, because we are going to depart for the 4 dimension! What if our world is folded just like Flatland (which is actually far from flat) and we can't even start to imagine how our world really is like. In that framework, entangled particles and spooky action at a distance are completely wrong ideas about the real world!

And here is why...

1st of all, (if all the above are correct) there would be no "spooky action at a distance" because 1st) there is no distance 2nd) there is nothing spookiness because these 2 entangled particles, can be thought to be so close together that could easily interact with each other while one of which is being observed, the other is also changing.

BUT furthermore! Something even cooler arises from that thought!
And that's that these 2 particles are not even 2 particles! They could very well be just one! A single particle! A particle that exist at the point where these 2 folded sides of Flatland (or our 3d world) are touching each other and simply this one particle exists in the 3rd dimension (of the 4th depending to which experiment we are talking about). That particle will look like 2, but it is actually just one and only! But it's a different particle than the ones we have been observing so far. It is a particle that exceeds our 2 dimensional world, or 3 dimensional world that has been folded tricking us to believe that there is spooky action at a distance between 2 particles...

Where in reality:

1) There is nothing spooky going on

2) There is no distance

3) There is no second particle

4) There are no particles in superposition

5) There is no information traveling faster than light

It is just one particle, with the only exception that it seems to extend to plus one dimension more than we do.

And finally we arrive at the solution of the second problem of, Superposition.

"How can something be at 2 states at the same time?" Well it might not! It might very well be spinning UP in the one "side of the paper" and DOWN "at the other", and when it is observed, the one snaps UP and the other DOWN. There is no big deal! Only everything takes place in a plus higher dimension where a single point can become a huge line and a single particle can be thought as 2 individual ones.

Lastly I wanna say, that we use to think as information is traveling "faster than light" when we talk about superposition. By that example that I just gave, information is not traveling faster than the speed of light, because information is not traveling at all ! There are no individual "entangled" particles! There is just one single particle! But because it exists in more than 3 dimensions, a lot of weird things can happen to trick us to believe that it has an enabled twin, that it is somehow connected and that somehow information is traveling faster than the speed of light... Just as string theory is suggesting, there might infact be extra dimensions crawled up in the planck length.

If so, then the weirdness of Quantum Mechanics, just... evaporates!

People often say that the measurement of one particle "instantaneously" affects the other particle. I say it's even "worse" than that. If the two measurements are far enough apart in space-time so that a light signal cannot connect them (IOW, you'd need faster-than-light communication between the particles), the events are said to be "space-like". And relativity tells us that the order in which such events occur is relative. So some observers would determine that the measurement of A occurred before that of B, while others might determine that the measurement B preceded that of A. (More specifically, if particle A is moving to the left, and B is moving to the right, an observer moving to the right would see the measurement of B first (after taking into account the delay due to the fact it takes time for light (or some other signal) to get from the measuring device to the observer). And similarly, an observer moving to the left would determine that measurement A happened first. This means that people trying to measure some superluminal speed connecting the two measurements are either wasting their time, or simply testing relativity -- depending on your point of view!

From 2:15 to 2:40 it is explained why each of the two particles do not possess a particular, defined spin. The reasoning given is that it is possible to arrange (say) a 50 percent chance that both particles would have the same spin, which it was said would violate the law of conservation of angular momentum.

However, what is not taken into account is that the measurement apparatus itself can alter the spin, the angular momentum, of each of the particles. In such a case, it must be concluded that the angular momentum of the apparatus itself is modified by the particles. So there is conservation of angular momentum, but it is in the sum of the particles and the apparatus, not the particles alone. Since the reasoning given in the video only considers the angular momentum of the particles it must be considered incomplete.

So the reasonable idea that particles possess an actual, particular, defined, spin is not ruled out. Thank you.

Saying that spins of the two entangled particles are always opposite is not correct. Because they are not "supposed" to be always opposite. They must rather obey the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle. The EPR paper of Einstein did not talk about single property for two entangled particles, but rather about two non-commuting properties of entangled particles. It was specifically about position x and moment p. So, Heisenberg uncertainty states that we cannot know exactly both x and p at the same time. But according to " fundamental conservation laws-particularly momentum conservation" Einstein's paper setup a situation where you should be able to know both x and p for both particles, which is in direct contradiction with Heisenberg uncertainty. So, either Quantum theory is incomplete, or particles adjust their information to make the uncertainty principle work. That is what the EPR paper was about.

Bohmian Mechanics provides an interpretation of quantum entanglement consistent with both relativity and Bell's inequality. The video's spin measurement arrow @1:00 actually provides a good way to intuitively visualize how quantum spin mathematics works.

Imagine a Z-axis perpendicular to the vertical Y-axis and horizontal X-axis of the arrow. The spin of the electron along the vertical Y-axis is then represented (as shown in the video) as a constant circular rotation of the particle in the XZ plane. The up-down polarity of the spin indicates whether the spin rotation is clockwise or counter-clockwise. The Z-axis is not a real-value coordinate in physical space, it is the imaginary axis of the electron's complex-valued Bohmian pilot wave along the X-axis.

When you next attempt to measure the particle's spin along the X-axis, you get a sequence of up-down spin polarity readings that average over time to zero. You can visualize these readings as binary projections of the phase angle of the particle's circular spin in the XZ plane, sampled at random intervals. I.E. when the phase of the XZ spin is positive, the spin along the Y-axis is CW, and when it's negative the spin is CCW. As the video goes on to show, spin measurements along non-perpendicular axes will produce averages corresponding to the inclination angle of the non-perpendicular axis.﻿

In Bohmian Mechanics, all measured quantities other than the position of the particle are produced by entanglement of the measuring device with the particle's pilot wave. Since spin is not actually a property of the particle itself, it is meaningless to imagine that a measured particle might somehow transmit information to its entangled partner particle instantaneously at a speed faster than light.

What happens instead is that the evolution of the pilot wave of the entangled pair of particles is altered by interaction with the measuring device. A pilot wave is not akin to an electromagnetic wave that propagates through 4D spacetime; it is a non-local modulation of spacetime itself that evolves in complex-dimensioned quantum configuration space. The dynamic geometry of spacetime is not limited by the speed of light; it modulates and expands instantaneously and non-locally as the wavefunction of the entire universe evolves over time. It is only the motions of particles and fields contained within 4D spacetime that are limited by the speed of light, not the quantum fluctuations in the geometry of spacetime itself.

You technically can use entangled states to "send" information.
Consider a game where Alice and Bob choose a number, 0 or 1, and they win if their outcome is the same but lose otherwise. If they are space-like separated and cannot communicate with each other, then you'd expect them to win 50% of the time. If they instead create an entangled state where both particles have the same spin, they can win 100% of the time instead. Each Alice and Bob take one of the entangled particles, measure it in the same direction and report 1 for spin up and 0 for spin down. Since each of the particles will always be in the same state as the other, this strategy wins 100% of the time.
So it's almost like Alice's measurement sent one bit of information to Bob faster than light - but no information is actually sent, there is no channel between Alice and Bob. The entangled state was "used" as one bit of information, faster than the speed of light could send it.

I don't want to be argumentative, since I'm not a physicist, and the two MIT people I know are actually split on the issue of QM entangling.  But let me point out a couple of things that jump out at this layman (me):

First, from a comment -- "We know the entangled particles must have undefined spins before we measure them because if they didn't they would sometimes give the same spin when measured in a direction perpendicular to their well-defined spins (and they never do)". -- A measurement perpendicular to the spin should result in an unknown quantity -- the fact that you were able to decide that it was up or down afterwards implies that your measurement was not perpendicular, which in turn would make the measurement of the second particle produce the opposite result.  Conclusion -- this is not what proves an undefined spin.

Second, your experiment does not make logical sense.  Why would an empirical count produce a different result than a statistical count?  This has nothing to do with QM, and indeed, if you assign the proper percentages to your choices (in the video starting at 6:10 or so), you will also get 50%. To do this using outright counts, you'll have to represent each of the positions in a 360 degree arc, and then count where the ups and downs are different. Your explanation of how quantum mechanics would solve this puzzle is exactly the correct way to solve the puzzle regardless of your belief in QM's conclusions, whereas the explanation for how..  non QM?  would solve the puzzle is wrong.  Seems to me you have to start with the premise that uncertainty is inherent, and then when you find certainty, you call it a phenomena, or a proof or both.  But what if you didn't start with the uncertainty in the first place?  What if you started with the ability to measure a quantum characteristic, and lo and behold, you get the same result at the other particle (with the opposite result of course)?

Here's something easy to understand that you can do with entangled particles but can't without. 

Imagine you and your twin grow up together but are separated from each other at one point and put into a prison. The jailor visits each of you in prison and hands over a red or green card. Both of you don't know what the other got. It could be the same color, or the opposite color. 

Now, the jailor challenges you to give to him a random sequence of binary numbers (1 or 0): If you both you and your twin have received the same colored cards, you must report the identical sequence. If both of you have received differently colored cards, you must each report completely uncorrelated sequences. 

If you succeed in this task, you are both freed from the prison immediately! 

This task is quite impossible without knowing what color your twin received.

But if you happened to have carried along entangled photons, you can do it without an issue! Simply measure the photons' polarization at an angle of 0° if you have a green card, and at 90° if you have a red card. If the measured polarization is up, report a 1, and if it's down, report a 0. Your twin must do the same but report a 0 or 1 instead. 

So there's something you can do with entanglement which you can't do without no matter what you try.

I subscribe to the many-worlds interpretation of decoherence. No ftl communication necessary upon observation, since a version of the observer is present for all possibilities.

When the opposing particles were created, so were two universes -- one containing the condition "A-up/B-down" and another "A-down/B-up". The state of coherence is merely a mathematical description of both universes being equally real.

Each universe contains an experimenter, but given the vast difference in scale between the spin conditions and everyday human experience, the parallel experimenters behave identically until the observation is made.

So while the split in universes occurred at the moment of particle creation, on the human scale the split in readily distinguishable world lines had to wait for the observer's conclusions. This gives the illusion of "communication" between the particles.﻿

I would suggest looking to a more classical example for Bell's inequalities. If you use ANY three properties of ANY population (say the operating system, hemisphere of Earth, and subscriber status of the viewers of this video, for example) the inequalities hold. They are true just in case there exists an answer to the question of what those properties are before they are measured. In quantum mechanics, the inequality is violated because that information is not merely unknowable, as Einstein believed, but nonexistent. Einstein thought that Heisenberg's uncertainty principal was about what we can KNOW. It turns out, as Bohr and others argued, it is about what there is, a much more profound result that ultimately proves there is true randomness in the universe. We do not live in a deterministic world. Unfortunately, John Bell reached his result several years after Einstein died and Alain Aspect finally performed the experiment to prove Bell right only in 1981.

I fail to see why this is "spooky."  If I flip two coins in such a way that one will always be "heads" and the other "tails," then that is a-priori information about the system.  So when I measure the outcome of one, then of course I now know information about the other.  There is nothing magical or counter-intuitive about this.

(edit:)  Yes, I know that photons are not classical particles like coins.  That's not the point!  The point I am making is that the experimental concept, in and of itself, is not what's "spooky."  It only gets spooky when the photons start producing unexpected correlations in violation of locality.  That's the spooky part!
